tweet: Normally, our democracy has several layers of "safety" built into its gov that make a military refusal to follow orders totally unneeded.
It is such a danger to democracy that it's hard to see a safe way forward after that point. Very much US version of crossing the Rubicon.
That conflict is understood to mean that "illegal order" equals something very very big & worth the risk to democracy to disobey.
So there's a conflict in training/socialization- you don't follow illegal orders, but also the civilians are in charge.
The military, deciding on its own, what orders are not legal- even if it's done rightly the first time sets a dangerous precedent.
The military hasn't done that so far, b/c of the knowledge that it'd likely open a door that couldn't be closed again.

This is something pretty strongly drilled into you - you don't follow illegal orders.

Even so, it'd be v/troubling. https://t.co/yiFj1mxqLK
